I think the premise of this discussion is
incorrect.  A URL is not a container.
Relationships between URLs are entirely client and
application driven.  If you think that one URL
contains another, specify that in some RDF
document.  And when you do, you need need to
precisely specify the meaning of this containment
relation:

1. Does deleting a container without first
   deleting its contents result in a 50x error?
2. Does deleting a container also delete all of
   its contents and disable any further
   GET/POSTs to the URL?
3. Does deleting a container simply empty its
   contents but allow further GET/POSTs to
   the URL?
[Note: these are equivalent to the issue of
referential integrity and cascading deletes from
the RDBMS world]

DELETEing a URL should simply mean that you can no
longer GET or POST to it.  Adding arbitrary side
effects just makes it more complex to interact
with your application.

Note: It would be great to solve the referential
integrity problem for the web, but I think that
goes WAYYY beyond the scope of this discussion.

Note: If you don't want the overhead of
downloading all the URLs in the collection and
deleting them one by one, you probably need the
container to handle a POST whose body is "delete
contents."  But handling this sort of message is
really an optimization and all the warnings about
optimizations apply here.

On Thu, 10 Apr 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:

> > Another possible model is to think of the alternative URIs like UNIX
> > hard links - you can keep deleting them until the last one is gone.
>
> I'm not sure about this (I'm not sure about anything, but especially
> this).  DELETE seems to work against the mapping of resource to
> representations, not against the mapping of identifier(s) to resources,
> as would be the case above.
>
> The linking and unlinking of identifiers to resources seems to be
> solely in the domain of the authority, not something exposed through
> the methods of HTTP.
